commentary: True.
words: It isn’t ever delicate to live.

commentary: Made me think— interesting way to consider our existence, and kind of want to illustrate this.
words: Humanity is young, and we’ve barely begun to understand our place in the cosmos. As we continue to look out from our planet and contemplate the nature of reality, we should remember that there is a mystery right here where we stand.

commentary: This is lovely— ties into the twice as bright, half as long idea, but grounded in morality.
secondary_source: Mackenzie Scott explaining her philanthropic philosophy, quoted in NOEMA newsletter
words: A candle as it diminishes explains, Gathering more and more is not the way. Burn, become light and heat and help. Melt.

commentary: Truer words have never been spoken!
words: A day spent reading is not a great day. But a life spent reading is a wonderful life.

commentary: Should try this sometime. Or not, at the current moment...
words: A friend says the best way to love the world is to think of leaving.

commentary: Made me SALTS
words: A lawn is nature under totalitarian rule.

commentary: On the allure of imaginary lives... also, somewhat, a contrast between negative and positive space of existence; proposing reality does not need to be defined in the context of the former.
secondary_source: New Yorker article on imagine alternate lives
words: A man commits himself and draws his own portrait, outside of which there is nothing. No doubt this thought may seem harsh. . . . But on the other hand, it helps people to understand that reality alone counts, and that dreams, expectations, and hopes only serve to define a man as a broken dream, aborted hopes, and futile expectations.

commentary: True shit.
words: A man receives only what he is ready to receive…. We hear and apprehend only what we already half know.

commentary: “...a helpful phrase to remember whenever you’re confronted with studies, articles or... maps. Abstractions are useful but can also be misleading because there are always hidden details and nuances. And should map and terrain differ, always follow the terrain.”
primary_source: Polish-American scientist and philosopher Alfred Korzybski
secondary_source: Designer and researcher Johannes Klingebiel in interview in Dense Discovery newsletter
words: A map is not the territory.

commentary: This made me actually laugh out loud.
words: A narcissist can’t die because then the entire world would end.

commentary: A quiet truth
words: A poem need not have a meaning, and like most things in nature often does not.

commentary: Note the last sentence— really like this idea.
primary_source: Sigrid Nunez, NYT article on friendship
words: A popular view has it that reading fiction can teach us empathy by making us understand that other people, including those who are completely different from us, are real. I believe the same possibility arises when we give a stranger our full attention. To be curious about another person is one of the highest forms of respect you can pay them.

A river passing through a landscape catches the world and gives it back redoubled: a shifting, glinting world more mysterious than the one we customarily inhabit. Rivers run through our civilisations like strings through beads, and there’s hardly an age I can think of that’s not associated with its own great waterway.

commentary: Life begins at the edge of your comfort zone, and all that jazz.
words: A ship at harbour is safe, but that‘a not what ships are for.

commentary: Interesting... came across this quote pulled at the beginning of the year. I like it.
words: A thought experiment courtesy of the Stoics. If you are tired of everything you possess, imagine that you have lost all these things.

commentary: This is lovely.
words: Above me, wind does its best to blow leaves off the aspen tree a month too soon. No use wind. All you succeed in doing is making music, the noise of failure growing beautiful.

primary_source: David Guterson, Snow Falling on Cedars
words: ...accident ruled every corner of the universe except the chambers of the human heart.

commentary: So lovely! Synergy, symbiosis.
words: All flourishing is mutual.

commentary: This makes me smile :)
words: All good things are wild and free.

commentary: Reminds me of “A map is not the territory,” the space between reality and perception.
words: All human knowledge takes the form of interpretation.

commentary: Interdependence.
secondary_source: Elizabeth Kolbert, Under a White Sky
words: All living things on earth are kindred.

commentary: Life — and reality— rooted in the dynamic.
primary_source: Octavia E. Butler, Parable of the Sower
words: All that you touch you Change. All that you Change changes you. The only lasting truth is Change.

commentary: Happy new year!
words: And now let us believe in a long year that is given to us, new, untouched, full of things that have never been.

commentary: I like this progression from the Steinbeck quote- stepwise, from not needing to be perfect to not needing to be good to being free.
words: And now that we don’t have to be good, we can be free.
And now that you don’t have to be perfect, you can be good.

commentary: Weighing the costs (and benefits) of these lose-lose situations...
words: And the day came when the risk to remain tight in a bud was more painful than the risk to blossom.

commentary: It’s the journey that matters… abs the cyclical nature of life.
words: And the end of all our exploring. Will be to arrive where we started. And know the place for the first time.

commentary: As complete as we are— yes.
secondary_source: Barry Lopez, Of Wolves and Men, paraphrasing Henry Beston
words: Animals move in another universe, as complete as we are, both of us caught at a moment in mid-evolution.

commentary: And thus, we kind of live in a world surrounded by magic. Thinking about it like that is kind of awesome, in the truest sense of the word.
words: ...any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic.
Art compliments biology, it provides the direct experience of alternate sense islands that biology investigates.

commentary: Remain grounded in reality and whatnot, I guess. No magical thinking!
words: As people who want live a good, full, unrestricted, adventurous real kind of life, there is concrete instruction we can follow: see what is.
Ask yourself about the kind of life you want: What would you do day to day, and with whom, and where? Consider the life you have. Do one thing today, however small, to close the gap between the two.

commentary: Really resonates with me because of my constant fear of forgetting/not writing things down or recording— seems like a sign of wisdom, maturity, peace
words: At some point in life the world’s beauty becomes enough. You don’t need to photograph, paint, or even remember it. It is enough.

commentary: Motivation
words: At the end of the day, we can endure much more than we think we can.

commentary: I like this way of looking at it.
words: ...awareness is learning to keep yourself company.

commentary: Be where your feet are...
words: Be patient toward all that is unsolved in your heart and to try to love the questions themselves like locked rooms and like books that are written in a very foreign tongue. Do not now seek the answers, which cannot be given you because you would not be able to live them. And the point is, to live everything. Live the questions now. Perhaps you will then gradually, without noticing it, live along some distant day into the answer.
Being fearless is committing to not doing less because of your fear.

commentary: Reminds me of how nonlinear the experience of time is— how I feel like location, connection, etc. completely skew my perception of how long things have been (in the moment and in hindsight).
words: Being with you, and not being with you, is the only way I have to measure time.

commentary: So true! You've got to walk out your talk!
words: Between saying and doing, many a pair of shoes are worn out.

commentary: Don’t exist on autopilot.
words: Between stimulus and response there is a space. In that space is our power to choose our response. In our response lies our growth and our freedom.

commentary: At times like this, especially true.
words: Books are the plane, and the train, and the road. They are the destination, and the journey. They are home.

commentary: Not quite sure what this means, but it’s settling, in a way. Reassuring.
secondary_source: Miriam Toews, All My Puny Sorrows
words: Breath, dreams, silence, invincible calm, you triumph.

commentary: Very relatable sentiment.
words: Bulimia becomes the place I return to again and again to be alone, to be underneath, to not feel so much, to feel it all, safely. Bulimia is the world I make for myself because I don’t know how to fit into the real world. Bulimia is my safe, deadly hiding place, where the only one who can hurt me is me. Where I’m far away and comfortable...

commentary: An interesting idea, and I think true, for me.
words: But ain’t that how we learn to be ourselves? Failing to impress them that matter most to us?

commentary: I like this. The wonder in learning.
secondary_source: Sara Hendren, What Can a Body Do?
words: But one day the “why” arises, and everything begins in that weariness tinged with amazement.

commentary: You cannot plan to be happy.
words: But the best pleasures are those for which we do not plan, and the worst part of pain is expecting it and trying to get away from it when it has come. You cannot plan to be happy. You can plan to exist, but in themselves existence and non-existence are neither pleasurable nor painful

commentary: Very, very true, and makes me smile.
primary_source: Charles Darwin, in a letter to Asa Gray
secondary_source: Mary Ruefle; Madness, Rack, and Honey
words: But the more I think the more bewildered I become; as indeed I probably have shown by this letter.

commentary: Take the first step. The argument against perfectionism.
words: Can anything be sadder than work left unfinished? Yes, work never begun.

commentary: In honor of Audre Lorde’s birthday... a concept I might try a little harder to embrace.
words: Caring for myself is not self-indulgence, it is self-preservation, and that is an act of political warfare.

commentary: Interesting perspective on how chance affects art, but also life. Intuition, spontaneity, all that jazz.
primary_source: Jerry Saltz, How To Be an Artist
words: Chance is the stunning aurora borealis of creativity—a flickering instantaneity that sweeps across the skies of your work, leaving a trail that can make your work richer and stranger and better.

commentary: “Pay attention, or accept the consequences of your failure.”
words: Choice of attention—to pay attention to this and ignore that—is to the inner life what choice of action is to the outer. In both cases man is responsible for his choice and must accept the consequences.

commentary: This is true, I think, especially in our hyper-individualized American culture.
words: Compassion is the radicalism of our time.

commentary: Love this conceptualization of our “third self”— in the newsletter that references this quote, the writer suggests that acknowledging that some things you want to do will be unpleasant goes a long way in removing yourself as an obstacle to doing them.
words: Creative work needs solitude. It needs concentration, without interruptions. It needs the whole sky to fly in, and no eye watching until it comes to that certainty which it aspires to, but does not necessarily have at once... But just as often, if not more often, the interruption comes not from another but from the self itself, or some other self within the self, that whistles and pounds upon the door panels and tosses itself, splashing, into the pond of meditation. And what does it have to say? That you must phone the dentist, that you are out of mustard, that your uncle Stanley’s birthday is two weeks hence. You react, of course. Then you return to your work, only to find that the imps of idea have fled back into the mist.

commentary: Kind of a grounding mantra... good to stay mindful.
words: Death does not concern us, because as long as we exist, death is not here. And when it does come, we no longer exist.

commentary: The power of perspective, I suppose.
words: Death is not waiting for us at the end of a long road. Death is always with us, in the marrow of every passing moment. She is the secret teacher hiding in plain sight. She helps us to discover what matters most.

commentary: Lovely. Power of nature.
words: Demons hate fresh air.

commentary: This is good. The unspoken cost of waiting for change— kinda like opportunity cost, I guess?
words: Disconnecting from change does not recapture the past. It loses the future.

commentary: Wish it was so easy to shift perspectives.
secondary_source: Eula Bliss, Having and Being Had
words: Do all your work as if you had a thousand years to live, and as if you knew you must die tomorrow.

commentary: Really like this.
words: Do not be daunted by the enormity of the world's grief. Do justly, now. Love mercy, now. Walk humbly now. You are not obligated to complete the work, but neither are you free to abandon it.

commentary: This seems simple, but is not something I’ve ever really thought before. Like it.
words: Do not seek to follow in the footsteps of the wise. Seek what they sought.

commentary: Seems like a good theory of change even at a societal level.
words: Do the best you can until you know better. Then when you know better, do better.

commentary: Perspective.
words: Do those things that incline you toward the big questions, and avoid the things that would reduce you and make you trivial.

commentary: Lovely, lovely, lovely.
words: Do we really believe that the human imagination can sustain itself without being startled by other shapes of sentience—by redwoods and gleaming orchids and the eerie glissando cries of humpback whales?

commentary: Too, too true.
words: Do what you love and you’ll never work a day in your life work super fucking hard all the time with no separation and no boundaries and also take everything extremely personally.

commentary: Mary Oliver, the queen of rhetorical questions.
words: Do you need a prod? Do you need a little darkness to get you going?

commentary: Also true, happy words.
words: Dogs leave paw prints on your heart.

commentary: Hello, March. The power of vulnerability.
words: Don't be afraid to be confused. Try to remain permanently confused. Anything is possible. Stay open, forever, so open it hurts, and then open up some more, until the day you die, world without end, amen.

commentary: Is this supposed to make me feel better about the shitty status of my life?
words: Don’t be too timid and squeamish about your actions. All life is an experiment.

commentary: Behind every decision you make...
words: Don’t forget the why.

commentary: Very mindfulness.
primary_source: Yongey Mingyur Rinpoche, In Love With the World
words: Don’t forget to make space in your life to recognize the richness of your basic nature... Everything you ever wanted is right here in this present moment of awareness.

commentary: Make the fucking changes. A reminder that time goes by, and I gotta stop waiting for things to happen and do it myself.
words: Don’t live the same year 75 times and call it a life.

commentary: I don’t really know what this means, but I like it!
primary_source: Emily Dickinson, writing to a man she loved but refused to marry
secondary_source: Eula Bliss, Having and Being Had
words: Don’t you know that “No” is the wildest word we consign to Language?

commentary: Going deep into how connected everything is to every thing else, over time and space.
words: Each time you look at a tangerine, you can see deeply into it. You can see everything in the universe in one tangerine. When you peel it and smell it, it’s wonderful. You can take your time eating a tangerine and be very happy.

commentary: Equanimity! Reminds me of the “Things are awful, things are great, things can be better” quote.
primary_source: Jerry Colonna, Reboot: Leadership and the Art of Growing Up
words: Equanimity boils down to this: Everything is great and I am ok. Everything sucks and I am ok.

commentary: Somewhere in between is where we need to be. Spectrums, the gray area and all that.
words: Eradicate the optimist who takes the easy view that human values will persist no matter what we do. Annihilate the pessimist whose ineffectual cry is that the goal's already missed however hard we try.

commentary: Lovely, lovely.
primary_source: George Saunders, 2013 convocation speech at Syracuse
words: Err in the direction of kindness.

commentary: Reassuring, I suppose. And good reminder into internal lives of everyone.
words: Everyone has their sadness. And most people are scared of it.

commentary: Very... existential. Fitting, given Yalom is an American existential psychiatrist at Stanford!
words: Existence cannot be postponed.

commentary: Tips for a good life.
words: Expect nothing. Live frugally on surprise.

commentary: Gratitude!
words: Expect nothing to be done, but when it is take refuge in incredulity.

commentary: Tattooable?
secondary_source: Kip, a dude in Christopher McDougall’s Running with Sherman
words: Fear that thing, do that thing.

commentary: Jives well with the power and value of curiosity, as emphasized by Walter Isaacson in The Code Breaker
words: Find wonder in all things...

commentary: Much needed motivation to move on and get to the next thing, and the next…)
words: Finish each day and be done with it. You have done what you could. Some blunders and absurdities no doubt crept in; forget them as soon as you can. Tomorrow is a new day. You shall begin it serenely and with too high a spirit to be encumbered with your old nonsense.

commentary: Very “fake it till you make it”
words: First we have to believe, and then we believe.

commentary: Important to consider, I guess, when thinking about the changes we are trying to enact in society today.
secondary_source: Eyeo Authors Talk with Kate Crawford & Jer Thorpe
words: For the master's tools will never dismantle the master's house.

commentary: Fitting/necessary motivation
words: Forget safety. Live where you fear to live.

commentary: So clever, and read this while listening to a book on foxes!
words: Fox is just cat software running on dog hardware.

commentary: An interesting perspective. Freedom is really just the space you have from those out to get you— and you always have to keep running to keep it safe.
secondary_source: Ocean Vuong, On Earth We’re Briefly Gorgeous
words: Freedom is nothing but the distance between the hunter and its prey.

commentary: I like this one a lot, and think it makes a lot of sense.
words: Future love does not exist. Love is a present activity only.

commentary: Agreed.
words: Happiness is a warm puppy.

commentary: Congruence, living a values-based life :)
words: Happiness is when what you think, what you say, and what you do are in harmony.

commentary: A good way to evaluate decor, I suppose. Prompted me to look quite critically around my house. That three-week-old “Welcome Home!” balloon...
secondary_source: Shelter in Place by David Leavitt
words: Have nothing in your house that you do not know to be useful, or believe to be beautiful.

commentary: “Ikkyū was an eccentric, iconoclastic Japanese Zen Buddhist monk and poet” Makes a good point about the danger of having expectations, too strict of a plan— makes you afraid of and blind to every other possibility.
words: Having no destination, I am never lost.

commentary: Yes
words: He wondered how we know that what happens to us isn’t good.

commentary: A similar message to the poem “The Basics,” the writer of The Whippet noted.
words: Hello babies. Welcome to Earth. It’s hot in the summer and cold in the winter. It’s round and wet and crowded. On the outside, babies, you’ve got a hundred years here. There’s only one rule that I know of, babies— Goddamn it, you've got to be kind.

commentary: So relatable, and a kinda poetic way to describe my issues.
primary_source: Claire Lombardo, The Most Fun We Ever Had
words: Her daughter was impulsive, compulsive, turbulent... She was self-conscious and self-critical and self-destructive.

commentary: My favorite message. Illustratable?
words: Here is the world: beautiful and terrible things will happen. Don’t be afraid.

commentary: Not just relevant to history on a societal scale, I think, but also on a personal one. Our narratives are so, so significant.
words: History is not the past. It is the stories we tell about the past. How we tell these stories—triumphantly or self-critically, metaphysically or dialectically—has a lot to do with whether we cut short or advance our evolution as human beings.

commentary: inspirational!
primary_source: Annie Lamott in Bird by Bird
words: “Hope begins in the dark, the stubborn hope that if you just show up and try to do the right thing, the dawn will come. You wait and watch and work: you don’t give up.”

commentary: Necessary reminder.
words: Hope is a renewable resource option: If you run out of it at the end of the day, you get to start over in the morning.

commentary: Very happy.
words: How delightful it is, and how it makes one's pulses bound to get back into this reviving northland wilderness! How truly wild it is, and how joyously one's heart responds to the welcome it gives, its waters and mountains shining and glowing like enthusiastic human faces!

commentary: Came across this while scrolling yesterday: reminds me how small my world feels these days.
primary_source: Writer and theologian G. K. Chesterton
words: How much larger your life would be if your self could become smaller in it; if you could really look at other men with common curiosity and pleasure … You would break out of this tiny and tawdry theatre in which your own little plot is always being played, and you would find yourself under a freer sky, in a street full of splendid strangers.

commentary: The interdependence of kife
secondary_source: Harriet A. Washington, A Terrible Thing to Waste
words: Humankind has not woven the web of life. We are but one thread within it. Whatever we do to the web, we do to ourselves.

commentary: I like this concept
words: Humor is a sacred tool for walking through the unspeakable.

commentary: Constant exploration!
words: I am always doing that which I cannot do, in order that I may learn how to do it.

commentary: This is extremely relatable.
words: I arise in the morning torn between a desire to improve (or save) the world and a desire to enjoy (or savor) the world. This makes it hard to plan the day.

commentary: My favorite theme… the power of skepticism.
primary_source: Carlo Rovelli, Helgoland: Making Sense of the Quantum Revolution
words: I believe that one of the greatest mistakes made by human beings is to want certainties when trying to understand something. The search for knowledge is not nourished by certainty: it is nourished by a radical absence of certainty. Thanks to the acute awareness of our ignorance, we are open to doubt and can continue to learn and to learn better. This has always been the strength of scientific thinking—thinking born of curiosity, revolt, change.

commentary: The overwhelm of possibilities...
words: I can never be all the people I want and live all the lives I want. I can never train myself in all the skills I want. And why do I want? I want to live and feel all the shades, tones and variations of mental and physical experience possible in my life.

commentary: We grow through what we go through, and all that. Two lessons: remember how much I’ve /learned/ from all this, and remember to /keep learning/ from it.
words: I can use pain to become... If I can sit in the fire of my own feelings, I will keep becoming.

commentary: Simple but profound, honestly.
words: I cannot be free if I am rejecting any part of my existence.

commentary: Simple motivation.
words: I cannot do all the good that the world needs, yet the world needs all the good I can do.

commentary: Agree.
secondary_source: Journalist, immigration rights activist and undocumented immigrant Jose Antonio Vargas In an interview for Politico’s Recast newsletter
words: I can't be a pessimist because I am alive. To be a pessimist means that you have agreed that human life is an academic matter. So, I am forced to be an optimist.

commentary: Very relatable today.
words: I feels frantic desire to free myself. To start all over again and in another way.

commentary: Constantly in the process of becoming, changing.
words: I have already lost touch with a couple of people I used to be.

commentary: Lovely
primary_source: Audre Lorde, A Burst of Light
words: I have always known I learn my most lasting lessons about difference by closely attending the ways in which the differences inside me lie down together.

commentary: Those things where you know you’ll feel good once you start, but have no motivation to do so…
words: I have remarked very clearly that I am often of one opinion when I am lying down and of another when I am standing up.

primary_source: Lord Byron, Childe Harold’s Pilgrimage, Canto III, St. 72 (1816)
words: I live not in myself, but I become // Portion of that around me; and to me // High mountains are a feeling, but the hum // Of human cities torture.

commentary: Not sure what it means, but I think I agree. I have to construct the framework with which I experience the world, or else I by default submit to someone else’s.
words: I must create a system, or be enslaved by another man’s. I will not reason or compare; my business is to create.

commentary: Found this on Pinterest awhile ago and want to draw it out. Speaks to me, the need for space and breathing room; the urge to run, to relax, to be— to feel alive, I guess. Or dogs. I don’t know which the last line is supposed to refer to, but I relate either way.
primary_source: Virginia Woolf, A Room of One’s Own
words: I need solitude. I need space. I need air. I need the empty fields round me; and my legs pounding along roads; and sleep; and animal existence.

commentary: Gets at the reality of things, doesn’t it?
primary_source: David Carr, The Night of the Gun
words: I now inhabit a life I don't deserve, but we all walk this earth feeling we are frauds. The trick is to be grateful and hope the caper doesn't end any time soon.

commentary: Good to remember
words: I think and think for months and years. Ninety-nine times, the conclusion is false. The hundredth time I am right.

commentary: In honor of my attempts to take things a little slower today— goes nicely with Jeff’s “Welcome to the party!” message, as well!
secondary_source: Mary Ruefle; Madness, Rack, and Honey
words: I think I will do nothing for a long time but listen, / And accrue what I hear into myself …. and let sounds contribute toward me.

commentary: Very existestential
words: I was peeling a red apple from the garden when I suddenly understood that life would only ever give me a series of wonderfully insoluble problems. With that thought an ocean of profound peace entered my heart.

commentary: Through equanimity, clarity…
words: I wish I could tell you it gets better, but it doesn’t get better. You get better.

commentary: Another very relatable sentiment.
words: I wonder which me is me— the one who is feeling the feelings, or the one who is scoffing at the feelings.

commentary: Beautiful and smiles.
secondary_source: Ellen Meloy, The Anthropology of Turquoise
words: I would like to do whatever it is that presses the essence from the hour.

commentary: Actually kind of scary how much this describes my mental state most of the time.
secondary_source: Randy Nesse, Good Reasons for Bad Feelings
words: Ideas won’t keep. Something must be done about them.

commentary: Maybe someone finally suggesting a positive role for expectations and hope— as a guide to your journey, more so than an essential outcome or event.
words: If one advances confidently in the direction of his dreams, and endeavors to live the life which he has imagined, he will meet with a success unexpected in common hours.

commentary: Duality & dialectic of reality. Interesting that it's dependent on truly loving life.
words: If our heart were large enough to love life in all its detail, we would see that every instant is at once a giver and a plunderer.

commentary: Relevant both on a societal level as she contextualizes it, and for individuals…
words: If we want people to save their own lives, then we need to make those lives good ones.
If you are idle, be not solitary; if you are solitary, be not idle
If you are unable to find the truth right where you are, where else do you expect to find it?

commentary: Very positive psychology! Don’t just survive; thrive.
words: If you ask “How can I make it through this?”, you’ll get answers that will help you survive. If you ask “How might this experience bring out the best in me?”, you’ll get answers that help you thrive.

If you pour a handful of salt into a cup of water, the water becomes undrinkable. But if you pour the salt into a river, people can continue to draw the water to cook, wash, and drink. The river is immense, and it has the capacity to receive, embrace, and transform. When our hearts are small, our understanding and compassion are limited, and we suffer. We can’t accept or tolerate others and their shortcomings, and we demand that they change. But when our hearts expand, these same things don’t make us suffer anymore. We have a lot of understanding and compassion and can embrace others. We accept others as they are, and then they have a chance to transform.

commentary: The little things.
words: If you show up every day, keep your word, be somebody who has dignity in the way you comport yourself, that’s quite astonishing.

commentary: Learning that this is the case. I’m good at the former, need to force myself to do the latter. As I am.
words: If you want to be a writer, you must do two things above all others: read a lot and write a lot. There's no way around these two things that I'm aware of, no shortcut.

commentary: Motivation/somewhat hopeful state for the future… kinda relates to Erin and my conversation, too, about the role of treatment in just keeping things going and buying time.
words: if you wanted to drown you could, but you don’t because finally after all this struggle and all these years you simply don’t want to any more, you’ve simply had enough of drowning and you want to live and you want to love

commentary: This is clever, and true regarding the reality of the external validation we crave.
primary_source: Cool Runnings (movie about the Jamaican Olympic bobsled team)
words: If you’re not enough before the gold medal, you won’t be enough with it.

commentary: For all the reasons— to work, to be a good human.
secondary_source: Jerry Saltz, How To Be an Artist
words: Imagination is more important than knowledge.

commentary: Just. Yeah.
words: In a world that entices us to browse through the lives of others to help us better determine how we feel about ourselves, and to, in turn, feel the need to be constantly visible, for visibility these days seems to somehow equate to success. Do not be afraid to disappear, from it, from us, for a while, and see what comes to you in the silence

commentary: I like this visual.
words: ...in an infinite universe, there is no individuality.
In order to arrive at what you do not know You must go by a way which is the way of ignorance.

commentary: Lopez cites this idea in the context of how we can move towards a new understanding of animals and the natural world.
secondary_source: Barry Lopez, Of Wolves and Men
words: In philosophical discussion, the merest hint of dogmatic certainty as to finality of statement is an exhibition of folly.

commentary: Beautiful.
secondary_source: Tracy K. Smith, in NYT Book Review
words: In the bigger scheme of things, the universe is not asking us to do something, the universe is asking us to be something. And that’s a whole different thing.

commentary: Relates to the idea of self-as-context, the true “Self,” calm, compassionate, curious...
words: In the depths of winter, I finally learned that within me there lay an invincible summer.
In the end, we will remember not the words of our enemies, but the silence of our friends.

commentary: On a Mary Oliver streak. The simplicity and striking relatability (resonance?) of her words is grounding to me, I think.
words: Instructions for living a life: Pay attention. Be astonished. Tell about it.

commentary: such a classic (want to illustrate)
secondary_source: The World is Flat — Tom Friedman
words: It doesn’t matter whether you are a lion or a gazelle: when the sun comes up, you’d better be running.

commentary: Is this related to the sunk cost fallacy? It’s true, though. You at least get the gratification of martyrdom, or recognition or something.
words: It is easier to sacrifice great than little things.

commentary: On the wonders of science, learning, and discovery… inspiring!
secondary_source: Elliot Hershberg, The Century of Biology newsletter
words: It is like a voyage of discovery into unknown lands, seeking not for new territory but for new knowledge. It should appeal to those with a good sense of adventure.

commentary: Yeah. Bystander effect sorta deal— and I feel like there’s an MLK quote that relates to this idea?
words: It is not only for what we do that we are held responsible, but also for what we do not do.

commentary: Curiosity! Grit!
words: It is not that I’m so smart. But I stay with the questions much longer.

commentary: A classic, and very true
words: It isn't the mountains ahead to climb that wear you out, it's the little pebble in your shoe.

commentary: Perspective that is never not appreciated.
words: It may be that when we no longer know what to do, we have come to our real work and when we no longer know which way to go, we have begun our real journey.

commentary: Yeah.
words: It takes courage to grow up and become who you really are.

commentary: Yeah, the in between time is hard. I don’t always have the guts.
words: It takes guts to live here: between anticipation and realization.

commentary: Nothing changes if nothing changes. Thanks, Alex.
words: It’s easier to act your way into a new way of thinking, than to think your way into a new way of acting.

commentary: Reminder. Gotta do the things for yourself, at the end of the day. Dolphin parents.
secondary_source: Hoda Kotb, I Really Needed This Today
words: It's your road, and yours alone. Others may walk it with you, but no one can walk it for you.

commentary: True...
words: I’ve never seen any life transformation that didn’t begin with the person in question finally getting tired of their own bullshit.
Joy is not in things, it is in us.

commentary: Brought a smile. Would be nice to illustrate. Include in Mom and Dad’s card?
words: Just living is not enough. One must have sunshine, freedom, and a little flower.

commentary: Sort of like, keep your head in the stars and feet on the ground. Dream big, but don’t get disconnected from reality.
primary_source: Yongey Mingyur Rinpoche, In Love With the World
words: Keep the view as vast as space. Keep your actions as fine as flour.

commentary: motivational! want to hear how it sounds.
words: Kia kaha (Māori interjection meaning “Be strong; stay strong; forever strong”)

commentary: Lovely and visual. To illustrate for Erin!
words: Kind hearts are the gardens, kind thoughts are the roots, kind words are the flowers, kind deeds are the fruits. Take care of your garden. And keep out the weeds. Fill it with sunshine, kind words, and kind deeds.

commentary: Lovely. Was trying to pin this one down for awhile.
words: Kindness is the only non-delusional response to the human condition.

primary_source: Seth Godin, Three types of kindness
words: Kindness multiplies and it enables possiblity. When we’re of service to people, we have the chance to make things better.

commentary: The whole, “you must help yourself before you can help others” thing.
words: Knowing how to be solitary is central to the art of loving. When we can be alone, we can be with others without using them as means of escape.

commentary: Buford wonders “if a modern version might be: Cooking is when things have a flavor that few of us know anymore?”
words: La cuisine, c’est quand les choses ont le goût de ce qu’elles sont. (Cooking is when things taste like what they are.)

commentary: I experience this a lot, figuring out what I mean in the process of articulating it.
words: Language is the mother, not the handmaiden of thought; words will tell you things you never thought or felt before.

commentary: beautiful metaphors + descriptions
primary_source: Donika Kelly, “When the Fact of Your Gaze Means Nothing, Then You Are Truly Alongside”
words: late spring wind sounds an ocean through new leaves. later the same wind sounds a tide… // the ocean an animal full of other animals.

commentary: Healthy skepticism! Want this to be my motto, or something like that
words: Less certainty, more inquiry

commentary: Life is hard, but it’s also wonderful. Stay for the wonder.
words: Let everything happen to you: beauty and terror. Just keep going. No feeling is final.

commentary: Kinda YOLO, kinda “if not now, then when?”, and I love it.
words: Life is very short and what we have to do must be done in the now.

commentary: Challenges the myth of the alcoholic writers, that being in pain and killing yourself is the path to creative genius.
words: Life isn’t a support system for art. It’s the other way around.

commentary: True. Novelty.
words: Life shrinks or expands in proportion to one’s courage.

commentary: Relativity is the unfortunate truth of moral quandaries, and of most things in life…
words: Life — the way it really is — is a battle not between Bad and Good, but between Bad and Worse.

commentary: I love this as a general principle to live by.
words: Listen and learn it. Learn to tell it. And tell it to teach it.

commentary: Means maybe there is a sense of fate or destiny out there.
words: Lives are like rivers. Eventually they go where they must, not where we want them to go.

commentary: Me personally, and humans as a collective, are both living out of touc with primal rhythms at the moment. See the toll.
words: Living out of touch with the primal rhythms of life takes a toll on us.

commentary: Perspective, of our lives in the context of humanity and the universe. Awe makes us feel small, and also inspires empathy, connectedness to the world. Good to remember when my problems seem so existential.
secondary_source: Jamil Zaki, The War for Kindness
words: Look again at that dot. That's here. That's home. That's us. On it, everyone you love, everyone you know, everyone you ever heard of, every human being who ever was, lived out their lives. The aggregate of our joy and suffering, thousands of confident religions, ideologies, and economic doctrines, every hunter and forager, every hero and coward, every creator and destroyer of civilization, every king and peasant, every young couple in love, every mother and father, hopeful child, inventor and explorer, every teacher of morals, every corrupt politician, every "superstar," every "supreme leader," every saint and sinner in the history of our species lived there--on a mote of dust suspended in a sunbeam.
Look, I want to love this world as though it’s the last chance I’m ever going to get to be alive and know it.

commentary: I love bewilderment, and this is a comforting plea to make, in a way.
words: Lord, increase my bewilderment.

commentary: Lovely image, and reminds me a lot of houseplants, for some reason
secondary_source: Isabel Allende, The Soul of a Woman
words: Love doesn’t grow like a wild plant, it needs a lot of care.

commentary: Accurate to my experience— dissipates as you get to know the person and see that they’re not as idealistic as they seem.
secondary_source: Randy Nesse, Good Feelings for Bad Reasons
words: Love is a gross exaggeration of the difference between one person and everybody else.

commentary: None needed. I like this.
words: Maybe wayfinding is an activity that confronts us with the marvelous fact of being in the world, requiring us to look up and take notice, to cognitively and emotionally interact with our surroundings whether we are in the wilderness or a city, even calling us to renew our species’ love affair with freedom, exploration, and place.

commentary: Had to search for this one, but I think it’s what I need in this moment.
words: My actions are my only true belongings. I cannot escape the consequences of my actions. My actions are the ground upon which I stand.

commentary: So lovely.
secondary_source: Ellen Meloy, The Anthropology of Turquoise
words: My God, happiness exists… and perhaps that’s all it is, sea, light, and vertigo.

commentary: A shift from how I usually do things, but how I feel best doing them.
words: My working habits are simple: long periods of thinking, short periods of writing.

commentary: Yes.
words: Never allow anyone to be humiliated in your presence.

commentary: Made me smile.
words: Never be cool. Never try to be cool. Never worry what the cool people think. Head for the warm people. Life is warm. You’ll be cool when you’re dead.

commentary: Or else we’re doomed to forever follow the status quo, converging on a uniform average… or, rather, a static hierarchy.
words: Never, ever be afraid to make some noise and get in good trouble, necessary trouble.

commentary: I get this feeling— when the buzz around the thing is anticlimactic, I feel sort of... uneasy because I feel normal, which is un-normal...
words: New Year’s Day everything is in blossom! I feel about average.

commentary: This is fun— can’t appreciate the ups without the downs and all. I like the visual!
words: No clouds, no rain; no rules, no gain.

commentary: Relevant to the whole Blue Zone idea, of living in the moment, treasuring connection and the present action.
words: No man can have a peaceful life who thinks too much about lengthening it.

commentary: So very relevant/relatable to my life, wow. Something to put into action.
words: No one cares how much you know until they know how much you care.

commentary: True shit.
words: No woman on earth doesn’t give a fuck—no woman is that cool—she’s just hidden her fire. Likely, it’s burning her up.

commentary: This is lovely.
words: Nothing can make our life, or the lives of other people, more beautiful than perpetual kindness.

commentary: Constant reminder that I have to make different choices if I want a different outcome.
words: Nothing changes if nothing changes.

commentary: I can change my mind, and changing my mind will change my world.
words: ...nothing is fixed, forever and forever and forever, it is not fixed... we made the world we're living in and we have to make it over.

commentary: A harsh reality.
words: Nothing is more unbearable, once one has it, than freedom

commentary: Relatable and sad.
words: Nothing is so painful to the human mind as a great and sudden change.

commentary: It’s okay to breathe, to pause, to rest.
words: Notice how the flowers still grow when the days are long and slow.

commentary: I like this... life begins at the end of your comfort zone!
words: Once we’re thrown off our habitual paths, we think all is lost, but it’s only here that the new and the good begins.

commentary: Found this one in search of a quote tonight, but it’s so fucking relevant to what I’m trying to do right now. And relevant to me doing the things to actually overcome, and to be able to give instead of take.
words: One day you will tell your story of how you’ve overcome what you are going through now, and it will become part of someone else’s survival guide.

commentary: Good reminder during hard times (AKA now)
words: One discovers the light in darkness, that is what darkness is for; but everything in our lives depends on how we bear the light. It is necessary, while in darkness, to know that there is a light somewhere, to know that in oneself, waiting to be found, there is a light.

commentary: Nothing changes if nothing changes….
words: One has to do something new in order to see something new.

commentary: (Renault wrote novels in the 1950s-70s set in Ancient Greece.)  Again, the importance of keeping a balanced perspective of how significant and insignificant we are in this world.
words: One must live as if it would be forever, and as if one might die each moment. Always both at once.

commentary: Honestly, a good way to both prioritise and de-prioritise the things I stress about getting done.
words: Only put off until tomorrow what you are willing to die having left undone.
Our deepest fears are like dragons guarding our deepest treasures.

commentary: Debatable...
words: Our economic system and our planetary system are now at war.... only one of these sets of rules can be changed, and it’s not the laws of nature.

commentary: I love this. There is no answer, there is no perfect solution… there’s nothing to wait for, you just gotta start living now.
words: Our suffering is believing there’s a way out.

commentary: I really, really like this as a summation for dealing with conflict.
primary_source: Sufi Piet Jalal al-Din Muhammad Rumi, 13th century
words: Out beyond ideas of wrongdoing and rightdoing, there is a field. I’ll meet you there.
परस्परोपग्रहो जीवानाम् = Parasparopagraho jivanam = All life is bound together by mutual support and interdependence

commentary: To keep in mind re: writing, art, schedule, life…
primary_source: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, author of The Little Prince
words: Perfection is achieved, not when there is nothing more to add, but when there is nothing left to take away.

commentary: Seems like the gist of this book, recommended by Ashley.
words: Pleasure is the point. Feeling good is not frivolous, it is freedom.
Practice kindness all day to everybody and you will realize you’re already in heaven now.

commentary: I don’t really know what this means, but the words and the idea make me happy :)
primary_source: Barbara Kingsolver, "How to Give Thanks for a Broken Leg"
words: Praise the careless syntax of a life where, through steady misuse, a noun grows feet: it turtles and outfoxes and one day, with no one watching, steps out as a brand-new verb.

commentary: Love the skepticism. And the sense of self-efficacy!
words: Re-examine all that you have been told... dismiss that which insults your soul.

commentary: Rediscovery? Not sure.
words: Re-seeing a hundred yesteryears you knew. // And spinning revolution in a circle—new.
Reality is never and nowhere more accessible than in the immediate moment of one’s own life. It’s only there that it can be won or lost.

commentary: Motivation to be mindful... no use in dwelling on the past of worrying about the future. Can only do what you can now.
words: Reality is never and nowhere more accessible than in the immediate moment of one’s own life. It’s only there that it can be won or lost.
Reality is not always probable, or likely.

commentary: Nice visual.
words: Remember light and shadow never stand still.

commentary: Nothing lasts forever- no feeling, no matter how intense.
words: Remember, light and shadow never stand still.

commentary: Life begins at the edge of your comfort zone, and all.
primary_source: Ocean Vuong, On Earth We’re Briefly Gorgeous
words: Remember: The rules, like streets, can only take you to known places.

commentary: (Need to confirm the wording...) One of the virtues of swimming— something I miss, I realize.
words: Renew thyself completely each day. Do it again, and again, and forever again.

commentary: I’m not entirely sure what this means, but it seems oddly relevant to my life right about now.
words: Rescue will come as a welcome interruption of your survival journey.
Resistance and change often begin in art, and very often in our art - the art of words.

commentary: Like the visual— reminder to stay connected with my true self, the underlying part
words: Respond from the center of the hurricane, rather than reacting from the chaos of the storm.

commentary: How I often feel about walking.
words: Right away, walking made me feel better. Every morning, when I stepped onto the road, I got a little less angry. It's easy to hate the world when it's just an abstraction that lives in your phone. It's harder when you are out there in it, really looking, interacting. Tiny moments felt hugely healing.

commentary: The complimentary nature of art and science in defining our realities
words: Science describes accurately from outside, poetry describes accurately from inside. Science explicates, poetry implicates.

commentary: Lovely, and want to illustrate. Good perspective for looking at the world.
words: See all human behaviour as one of two things: either love, or a call for love.

commentary: I really, really love this, and resonate with the imagery, Abe want to remember this.
words: She imagined accepting it all. The way she accepted nature. The way she accepted a glacier or a puffin of the breach of a whale. She imagined seeing herself as just another brilliant freak of nature. Just another sentient animal, trying their best. And in doing so, she imagined what it was like to be free.

commentary: A reminder that there is no neutral stance, and that not having an opinion is agreeing with the status quo.
words: Silence in the face of oppression is complicity with the oppressor.

commentary: Shared by Erin from Hoda Kotb’s book. Highlights importance of mental rest— the constant push for productivity can’t be solved without a break.
words: Sleep doesn’t help if it’s your soul that’s tired.
So few grains of happiness / measured against all the dark / and still the scales balance

commentary: Touched my heart
words: So I let the waves crash on my knees and thought about how the world doles out beauty to the in-love and the heartbroken alike. Nothing we do, and nothing we don't do, would stop them. I was the only one who ever saw those particular waves at the particular time. Why me?

commentary: A classic, but I need this sometimes when things seem impossible.
secondary_source: Harriet A. Washington, A Terrible Thing to Waste
words: Start where you are. Use what you have. Do what you can.

commentary: ...to unlock the other world that exists in this one. The order and certainty that naming, collecting and categorizing gives us is often an illusion, and masks the multitude of realities.
primary_source: Lulu Miller, Why Fish Don’t Exist
words: Stay wary of words...

commentary: Need to remember this…
words: Stop measuring your days by degree of productivity. Start experiencing them by degree of presence.

primary_source: Jamil Zaki, The War for Kindness
words: Stories are a performance-enhancing technology for untethering in time.

commentary: Reasons for literature and narrative
words: Story is our only boat for sailing on the river of time.
Study hard what interests you the most in the most undisciplined, irreverent and original manner possible.

commentary: How to notice things, I suppose? The power of the unexpected?
words: Surprise is the great enabler of seeing.

Take in more, consume less, recycle everything; book-keep all hidden costs; find out where you have been set down; lobby for a smaller market; get rid of your car and travel as widely as you can (yeah, walk: what the hell); try to say a little more than you mean; carry a pocket encyclopedia (ask for one without packaging) and when the entry on “Diffusion Constant” says, “for more information, see ‘Pastry War,'” see “Pastry War.”

commentary: Good message to remember! And to write out— maybe on post-card?
words: Take time out of your day to dream. Envision a life that inspires you. We can easily box ourselves into a certain way of living, confined by self- and culturally-imposed limits. Intentional dreaming can re-energize & re-inspire us to grow a life that we're excited about. It can also be scary to imagine having what you truly want. So don't let discomfort be a sign that you're doing it wrong.

commentary: Sounds kinda Mary Oliver, I think.
words: Take time to marvel at the wonders of life.

commentary: Originally meant about writing, but, I see this much more widely applicable to other disciplines, to life in general.
words: Talent is insignificant. I know a lot of talented ruins. Beyond talent lie all the usual words: discipline, love, luck, but most of all, endurance.

commentary: Relatable today. And couldn’t find anything else…
words: Thank God for books as an alternative to conversation.
The action alone is your mandate, / Never the fruits at any time.

commentary: Knowledge, should be a new category!
words: The beginning of knowledge is the discovery of something we do not understand.

commentary: Feel like I need a whole new category for quotes on knowledge and humility.
secondary_source: Noah Smith interview with Julia Galef
words: The best lack all conviction, while the worst are full of passionate intensity.

commentary: Letting your thought come and go...
words: The best way to control cow & sheep is to give them a big grazing field.

commentary: A little cheesier than my taste, but sometimes this sort of simplest motivation is the most applicable. Also, fitting, given that Blyton is a children’s book author!
words: The best way to treat obstacles is as stepping stones. Laugh at them, tread on them, and let them lead you to something better.

commentary: Relevant to conversation Jason and I were having today about science, and how to deal with data that doesn’t fit your paradigm.
words: The boldness of asking deep questions may require unforeseen flexibility if we are to accept the answers.

commentary: Acceptance as the first step in moving on.
secondary_source: Tim Ferriss podcast with Richard Schwartz
words: The curious paradox is that when I accept myself just as I am, then I can change.

commentary: This is me re: willfulness a lot, I think.
words: The desire to exercise your autonomy might motivate you to turn against the expected, the reasonable, and the moral—to show yourself, and perhaps others, that you are free.

commentary: RT. What is science even for?
words: The dirty little secret of genomics is that we know next to nothing about how a genome translates into the particularities of a living breathing individual.

commentary: I love this imagery, and want to illustrate.
words: The earth would die if the sun stopped kissing her.

secondary_source: Julia Galef, interview with Noah Smith
words: The first thing is that you must not fool yourself – and you are the easiest person to fool.

commentary: Can’t wait around for things to happen— the world is ready, we just have to start.
words: The good life gives no warning. It weathers the climates of despair and appears, on foot, unrecognized, offering nothing, and you are there.

commentary: I like this— delayed gratification as motivation for current action.
secondary_source: Andrew J. Hoffman, “Climate Change and Our Emerging Cultural Shift”
words: The great French Marshall Lyautey once asked his gardener to plant a tree. The gardener said ‘why plant it? It won’t flower for 100 years.’ ‘In that case,’ the Marshall replied, ‘plant it this afternoon.’

commentary: So very true.
secondary_source: Sigrid Nunez, What Are You Going Through
words: The literal meaning of life is whatever you do that stops you from killing yourself.

secondary_source: Sigrid Nunez, What Are You Going Through
words: The love of our neighbor in all its fullness simply means being able to say to him, “What are you going through?”

commentary: The power of awe, of noticing, and paying attention.
secondary_source: The Art of Noticing, via swissmiss
words: The moment one gives close attention to any thing, even a blade of grass, it becomes a mysterious, awesome, indescribably magnificent world in itself.

commentary: Describing the theme of Rachel Carson's “Undersea”— beautiful phrasing, and want to read this full essay
words: The ocean is a tangible way for humans to contemplate the cast interconnectedness of life...

commentary: Relevant very much right now. Going on the board.
words: The only thing that makes life possible is permanent, intolerable uncertainty: not knowing what comes next.
The opposite of a truth is a falsehood; but the opposite of a profound truth may be another profound truth.

commentary: Written in the context of mental illness (both anxiety and schizophrenia are serious diseases, but there is still a significant difference in how they impact individuals, how society needs to address for them), but this applies to my entire “all discretization is a human construct” belief! Spectrums don’t preclude differences.
words: The paradox of binaries is that they don’t mean there is no spectrum, just as a spectrum doesn’t mean there are no essential differences. A murky border is still a border. The problem was knowing who had the authority to establish it.

commentary: Curiousity-driven science, and the role of art and aesthetics...
words: The scientist does not study nature because it is useful. He studies it because he takes pleasure in it, and he takes pleasure in it because it is beautiful.

commentary: Once again, emphasizes importance of doing for the sake of the present moment; curiosity-driven science; impossibility of planning every aspect of life for maximum efficiency/productivity
words: The search for meaning, much like the search for pleasure, must be conducted obliquely. Meaning ensues from meaningful activity: the more we deliberately pursue it, the less likely are we to find it.

commentary: (But this power may be our life) Intriguing.
secondary_source: Mary Ruefle; Madness, Rack, and Honey
words: …. the secrets we choose to betray lose power over us.

commentary: True.
words: The test of a first-rate intelligence is the ability to hold two opposed ideas in the mind at the same time, and still retain the ability to function.

commentary: I like this imagery.
words: The universe is the wreckage of the infinite on the shores of the finite.

commentary: Conveys a nice image of the subjectivity of perception, with an added twist of efficacy (if we cultivate a different world within, can we cause such a different external experience that it is mirrored by actual change?)
words: The way we experience the world around us is a direct reflection of the world within us.

commentary: Lovely.
words: The world appears beautiful so that the living may love being alive in it.

commentary: Not sure what this means, but it’s making me think.
words: the world is a wonder, but the portions are small

commentary: Cynical, but I think describes me. Negativity bias and all.
words: The world is full of wonders and miracles but man takes his little hand and covers his eyes and sees nothing.

commentary: Wonder, awe, attention, nature
words: The world is full of magic things, patiently waiting for our senses to grow sharper

commentary: … on the justification of frugal science
words: The world needs designers that can understand partial differential equations.

commentary: Getting stuck in habits forever...
words: The worst labyrinth is not that intricate form that can entrap us forever, but a single and precise straight line.

commentary: Given the number of times I have “drawn my wall,” I think this is true.
words: The worst walls are never the ones you find in your way. The worst walls are the ones you put there.

commentary: This is so lovely.
words: There are a hundred thousand species of love, separately invented, each more ingenious than the last, and every one of them keeps making things.

commentary: Beautiful
words: αρχας ειναι των ολων ατόμους και κενόν, τα δ'αλλα πάντα νενομίσθαι There are atoms, and the spaces between them; surmise makes up the rest.

commentary: Lovely last word, and very relatable words right now.
words: There are desires to return, to love, to not disappear, and there are desires to die, fought by two opposing forces that have never isthmused.
There are two ways of spreading light: to be the candle or the mirror that reflects it.

commentary: Surprised I haven’t included this one yet— so very relevant to the past months.
words: There are years that ask questions, and years that answer them.

commentary: True shit. The power of interpretation, emotional responses, etc. to change how we react to and learn from events. Have a growth mindset!
secondary_source: Jamil Zaki, The War for Kindness
words: There is nothing either good or bad, but thinking makes it so.

commentary: To memorize, have hope, keep going
words: Therefore I tell you, whatever you ask for in prayer, believe that you have received it, and it will be yours.

commentary: Complexity systems.
words: There's no love in a carbon atom, No hurricane in a water molecule, No financial collapse in a dollar bill.

commentary: As an example of the Life Evolver technique of autobiography, pioneered by Frederick Douglass
words: There’s power in allowing yourself to be known and heard, in owning your unique story, in using your authentic voice. And there’s grace in being willing to know and hear others. This, for me, is how we become.

commentary: Article about the world maybe being the crazy ones, and the people who think it's insane are... not. Kind of disturbing, but hints of truth.
words: They took him on a stretcher To the Home for the Appalled Where he lay down in the corner And he bawled and bawled and bawled. 'There's nothing wrong with me,' he wailed, When asked about his bawling, 'It's the world that needs attention; It's so utterly appalling,'

commentary: Don’t know why, but this seems awfully fitting for today. Sorta existential, too.
words: Things are either devolving toward, or evolving from, nothingness.

commentary: Power of mindfulness, and of single-tasking
words: This is the real secret of life -- to be completely engaged with what you are doing in the here and now. And instead of calling it work, realize it is play.

commentary: Weather these days
words: This thing called rain can make the days seem short and the nights seem long.

commentary: Interdependence, the truth.
words: This we know: the earth does not belong to man, man belongs to the earth. All things are connected like the blood that unites us all. Man did not weave the web of life, he is merely a strand in it. Whatever he does to the web, he does to himself.

commentary: Quoted in the context of people experiencing severe anxiety about the current state of the world, with climate change and all— those who are considered “insane” or sick.
secondary_source: Samuel Alexander, article in The Conversation
words: Those who were seen dancing were thought to be insane by those who could not hear the music.

commentary: And, and, and. I think this will be my life motto.
words: Three things are true at the same time. The world is much better; the world is awful; and the world can be much better.

commentary: Have always liked this, since I captioned that Instagram post of me in the Grand Cayman with it!
words: Tiger got to hunt, bird got to fly; Man got to sit and wonder 'why, why, why?' Tiger got to sleep, bird got to land; Man got to tell himself he understand.

commentary: Came across this quote several times since first reading it in Brain Pickings; it's an inspirational and empowering interpretation of self with lots of implications that require more thought than I've yet given them!
words: Time is the substance I am made of. Time is a river which sweeps me along, but I am the river; it is a tiger which destroys me, but I am the tiger; it is a fire which consumes me, but I am the fire.

commentary: Less is more, often.
words: To attain knowledge, add things every day. To attain wisdom, subtract things every day.

commentary: Very true.
words: To be human is to confuse a satisfying story with a meaningful one.

commentary: Yes. Functional.
words: To get out of your anger, you can close your eyes and visualize the other person in 300 years. What will they become? Ash. And you too.

To live in this world you must be able to do three things: to love what is mortal; to hold it against your bones knowing your own life depends on it; and, when the time comes to let it go, to let it go.

commentary: Made me smile :)
secondary_source: Mary Ruefle; Madness, Rack, and Honey
words: To live is so startling, it leaves but little room for other occupations.

commentary: Lovely— on the different world views of forms of life.
words: To sense this world of waters known to the creatures of the sea we must shed our human perceptions of length and breadth and time and place, and enter vicariously into a universe of all pervading water.

commentary: A lovely articulation of our interdependence.
words: Tomorrow belongs to those of us who conceive of it as belonging to everyone, who lend the best of ourselves to it, and with joy.

commentary: Love this.
words: Tomorrow is tomorrow. Future cares have future cures, and we must mind today.

commentary: Very relevant to me right now as I try to make decisions.
words: Traveler, there is no path; paths are made by walking.

commentary: Have to think hard to conceptualize this.
primary_source: Erich Fromm, The Art of Listening
words: Understanding and loving are inseparable. If they are separate, it is a cerebral process and the door to essential understanding remains closed.

commentary: The distinction between the efficacy of feeling distress and feeling concern for others— the former inhibits our ability to help and can lead to emotional burnout, while the latter spurs kindness.
primary_source: Jamil Zaki, The War for Kindness
words: Understanding binds, but feelings blind.

commentary: Making the world both literally (desire lines and such) and figuratively (a mental perception), I guess.
secondary_source: Sara Hendren, What Can a Body Do?
words: Walking is a mode of making the world as well as being in it.

primary_source: Indigenous Declaration on Water, 2001 (Ancient Hopi message)
words: Water sustains all life. Her songs begin in the tiniest of raindrops, transform to flowing rivers, travel to majestic oceans and thundering clouds and back to earth again. When water is threatened, all living things are threatened.

commentary: Ambition? Hope? Reality? Perspective?
words: We are all in the gutter, but some of us are looking at the stars.

commentary: A nice visual— could be cool to illustrate
words: We are all one question, and the best answer seems to be love — a connection between things.

commentary: More reason to feel the pain, to stop avoiding and running away.
words: We are healed from suffering only by experiencing it to the full.

commentary: Thought-provoking.
words: We die. That may be the meaning of life. But we do language. That may be the measure of our lives.

commentary: Projecting? I guess we are hyper-aware of these things, because probably so much shame and fear around them.
words: "We discover in ourselves what others hide from us, and we recognize in others what we hide from ourselves.”

commentary: Beautiful metaphor.
words: We have less time than we knew, and that time buoyant and cloven, lucent, and missile, and wild.

commentary: How our reality is really very subjective.
words: We hear and apprehend only what we already half know.

commentary: Yes— I know this with certainty in the context of learning at school, science and language and all. But I think it’s a cool concept to apply to life lessons/emotional things, as well.
words: We move what we’re learning from our heads to our hearts through our hands.

commentary: I think I spent the first half of adulthood suffering the former, and now, the latter.
words: We must all suffer one of two things: the pain of discipline or the pain of regret.

commentary: Truth (meta!)
words: We must always be disturbed by the truth.

commentary: Humbling. And sort of freeing?
words: We must remember that nothing in this world really belongs to us. At best, we are merely borrowers.

commentary: Goes along with that bio quote that I can’t remember right now.
primary_source: Giambattista Vico, a Counter-Enlightenment scholar who lived between 1668 and 1744
words: We only know what we make.

commentary: In her words: “Home is everywhere and everything is cyclical. It’s always our eyes and explorations that are changing.”
primary_source: T. S. Eliot in Four Quartets
words: We shall not cease from exploration, And the end of all our exploring, Will be to arrive where we started, And know the place for the first time.

commentary: “The message is the medium,” and all— so relevant to the current age of social media and artificial intelligence.
words: We shape our tools and thereafter our tools shape us.

commentary: Confirmation bias, perhaps, when what we believe is not the whole picture? We want things to be simpler than what they truly are.
words: We swallow greedily any lie that flatters us, but we sip only little by little at a truth we find bitter.

commentary: Yes, I believe this. We tell ourselves stories to make sense of our perceptions, to justify our existence and our choices and our sense of choice.
words: We tell ourselves stories in order to live.

commentary: Beautiful.
words: We translate the earth’s language into our own, and enrich the already bright and colorful surface of the present with the knowledge of the inexhaustible abundance of the past.

commentary: Anti-inspiration, I guess— but relatable, always fighting against the path of least resistance.
words: We waste our energy and exhaust ourselves with the insistence that life be otherwise.

We’re like snow globes. We spend all of our time, energy, words, and money creating a flurry, trying not to know, making sure that the snow doesn’t settle so we never have to face the fiery truth inside us—solid and unmoving.... We keep ourselves shaken up because there are dragons in our center.

commentary: Need to think deeper about this.
words: What has drawn the Modern World into being is a strange, almost occult yearning for the future.

commentary: This is a little too close to home, re: months in treatment.
words: “What has retention taught her, these last few months? That the whole world can shrink to a room. That time is the God of all things. That the rules don’t have to make sense. That no matter how unjust the system is, she is expected to submit to it, in order to prove that she deserves to be free of its control.”

commentary: Motivation to break out of my stupid routines and habits— I know where they lead, so what’s the point of infinitely following them to oblivion?
primary_source: Mary Oliver, “If I Wanted a Boat”
words: What kind of life is it always to plan / and do, to promise and finish, to wish / for the near and the safe? Yes, by the / heavens, if I wanted a boat I would want / a boat I couldn’t steer.

commentary: The joys of hypothesis-generating
secondary_source: Randy Nesse, Good Reasons for Bad Feelings
words: What people think of as the moment of discovery is really the discovery of the question.

commentary: Interdependence of all things...
words: What the plants are quietly breathing out, we animals are breathing in; what we breathe out, the plants are breathing in. The air... is the soul of the visible landscape, the secrets realm from whence all beings draw their nourishment.
… what we do today, right now, will have an accumulated effect on all our tomorrows.

commentary: In support of, “the map is not the territory”
words: What you see and what you hear depends a great deal on where you are standing.

commentary: (His thoughts while looking out over a gathering of people paying their respects for him after winning the Nobel Peace Prize, while simultaneously sending more troops to war.) Reminds me of the importance of intentions, of learning from mistakes, of never waiting until the situation changes to change.
words: Whatever you do won’t be enough... Try anyway.

commentary: Such beautiful words, and relevant to the constant presence of possibility, self-efficacy, hope.
words: When day comes we step out of the shade, aflame and unafraid. The new dawn blooms as we free it. For there is always light, if only we’re brave enough to see it If only we’re brave enough to be it.

commentary: A very nice way to think about science! Constant questioning— and relevant to how to generate research questions given the vast amount of data we have out there (that’s it’s power, helping us ask better questions)
words: When I was a teen and trying to put it all together, I thought life was a matter of figuring out the answers to questions and that was that. Now I’m learning that good answers lead to better questions, and that cycle never ends.

commentary: Shame heals when spoken, and all.
words: When people shine a little light on their monster, we find out how similar most of our monsters are.

commentary: Intellectual humility, and all that!
words: When the facts change, I change my mind. What do you do, sir?

commentary: Acceptance, then adaptation. Evolution instead of resistance in the face of change.
words: When the winds of change blow, some build walls. Others build windmills.

commentary: In a lose-lose situation, all you can do is choose the option that keeps you truer to your Self. It’s usually harder, but it’ll be hard either way...
words: When we speak, we are afraid our words will not be heard or welcomed. But when we are silent, we are still afraid. So it is better to speak.

commentary: I love this. Reality is interaction, and all.
words: ...when we try to pick out anything by itself, we find it hitched to everything else in the universe.

commentary: Like the visual of this, and the idea of the serendipity of treasure.
words: When you stumble— there lies your treasure

commentary: I appreciate the direct simplicity.
primary_source: Mary Ruefle, Madness, Rack, and Honey
words: When your pencil is dull, sharpen it. And when your pencil is sharp, use it until it is dull again.

commentary: Agreed.
words: When you're curious, you find a lot of interesting things to do.

commentary: True on a scientific and philosophical level.
words: Which stories we honor... that is the difference between being kept and being free.

commentary: Made me smile :)
words: Why all the embarrassment about being happy? Sometimes I'm as happy as a sleeping dog, and for the same reasons, and for others.

secondary_source: Harold Evans, Do I Make Myself Clear?
words: ...words are the only things that last forever; they are more durable than the eternal hills.

commentary: Lovely visual, and cool conception for the function of language.
primary_source: Susan Brind Morrow, The Name of Things
secondary_source: Ellen Meloy, The Anthropology of Turquoise
words: Words begin as description. They are prismatic, vehicles of hidden, deeper shades of thought. You can hold them up at different angles until the light bursts through in an unexpected color.
Write with the door closed. Rewrite with the door open.

commentary: The meaning of life?
words: You are born alone. You die alone. The value of the space in between is trust and love.

commentary: No getting around it. Actions speak louder than words, and all that jazz.
words: You are what you repeatedly do.

commentary: All the inspiration. Always needed.  Nothing changes if nothing changes.
words: You become strong by doing the things you need to be strong for.

commentary: Running away from fear and anxiety does not equate to finding joy or pleasure. Choosing to go towards something is different than avoiding or numbing out.
words: You cannot find peace by avoiding life.

commentary: “Life is uncertain. Have faith that your dots will somehow connect.”
secondary_source: Swiss Miss link to a Twitter thread
words: You can’t connect the dots looking forward; you can only connect them looking backward. So you have to trust that the dots will somehow connect in your future.

commentary: The honest truth.
words: You can’t get away from yourself by moving from one place to another.

commentary: Kind of existential, but ultimately true. Reality is interaction, and all.
primary_source: Rumaan Alam, Leave the World Behind
words: You demanded answers, but the universe refused. Comfort and safety were just an illusion. Money meant nothing. All that meant anything was this—people, in the same place, together. This was what was left to them.

commentary: Not exactly sure what this means, but it sounds fancy.
words: You must live life with the full knowledge that your actions will remain. We are creatures of consequence.

commentary: True shit.
words: Your strategy for living in the present will go a lot better when you accept how frequently the present sucks.

commentary: Kind of how I feel about everyone who’s seen me at my worst, my parents & team who don’t believe I can do things differently... and maybe even myself, when I don’t believe I can do hard things.
words: You've seen my descent, now watch my rising.

commentary: This is relevant at a personal and societal level... another quote capturing the Lucretian Paradox.
words: Reality does not require human belief to be real.

commentary: Cited in the context of climate change and its exponential effect on wildfires, as well as our inability to imagine the true worst-case-scenario (see also, the Lucretian Paradox: we can’t imagine what we haven’t personally experienced; the worst thing that can happen has already happened).
words: The greatest shortcoming of the human race is our inability to understand the exponential function.
What goes too long unchanged destroys itself. The forest is forever because it dies and dies and so lives.
commentary: We exist in a dynamic equilibrium, etc.
(In the epigraph) I'm only 27 but feel this a lot.
words: The world is weary of me, And I am weary of it.

commentary: Really do feel like this is my experience-- I just don't know another way to be a human (adult human) that isn't sick.
words: And now that I’ve survived, I’m realizing I don’t know how to live.

commentary: Words to live by.
words: Tomorrow may happen, tomorrow may not… you have to shift from the gloom and doom and focus instead in what you love…. That’s all you can do in the face of these things. Love the people around you. Love the life you have. I can’t think of a more powerful response to life’s sorrows than loving.
